Fields.DialogueText: Captain! I need your help.
Hold on. I just need to brace myself appropriately.
... Just what have the other Belles asked you to do?
Nothing we need to dwell on.
Such a hard life you lead among ravishing ship spirits. This will be easy, though!
Now I'm really concerned.
I need your help thinking up a new plan.

Fields.MenuText: A plan for what, exactly?
A new battle plan? We'll cover it at the weekly tactical meeting.
If this ends with us hunting down a Morgana battleship again...

Fields.DialogueText: That's just the thing. I'm... not entirely sure.
Wrong kind of plan, Captain, but good thinking.
It won't! Probably!
With Treason handed a black eye and my reputation repaired, I find my hands idle.
Idle hands being the devil's playground, I need some sort of project to work on.
Something that plays to my strengths, my full suite of skills... not just fighting.
I see why you've been having a tough time with this. It seems like just yesterday I couldn't get you to a diplomatic function without the promise of a decapitation.
Well, it would have been gauche of me to show up without a gift.
*ALARM*
And here come exhibits A through... however many.
@BATTLE
Captain! Who was that who just left your office? I didn't recognize him.
That would be Commander Sir Edward Redviper, Royal Navy and now INPF personnel officer for this region.
He was talking to me about some of the morale issues we're facing.
Now there's a constant battle. Sailors far from home can always be happier.
I agree. Though I'm not sure about some of his suggestions. Hiring a trio of wandering Italian chefs he knows to supplement our galley crew, for example.
If they were any good, would they really be wandering?
Apparently they used to cook for General Melchett and Field Marshal Sir Douglas Haig during the Great War.
They must be ancient by now! Still, what's the use of improving things for just one ship?

Fields.MenuText: I agree. If anything, have them teach our cooks how to innovate with galley fare.
Just as long as they don't start a god-awful propaganda rag.
Showing regular people what's out here could go along way. The other world war, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: An astute suggestion, if they're really that skilled.
You never know when you might run low on toilet paper.
One we're all fighting. Save perhaps for the most landlocked of nations, and even they do what they can.
I'll have to think about it.
Well, let me know if you have any flashes of inspiration. I'm sure Redviper and his superiors would be very interested.
*ALARM*
Inspiration's my business, Captain! Not to mention the occasional scrap...
@BATTLE
Nasty out there, isn't it?
I'll whip things back into tune, Captain.
Pardon?
Oh, you'll see, Captain. You'll see.
@BATTLE
Noisy out on deck today. Band practice?
Band practice indeed. Recruit's really got them working hard today.
Captain, Lieutenant! Did you appreciate the concert?
Excellent as always. I wouldn't expect a ship this size to have a full band.
What the skipper said. If you'll excuse me...
I always feel better after hearing the band play their hearts out.
Music tends to do that to people.
Maybe that's something we can do for fleet morale! A new song, perhaps?

Fields.MenuText: For the whole INPF? That's a tall order.
I know the crew appreciates it, but that's hard to replicate on a fleetwide scale.
No, I think it's missing something. We need a broader brush to paint with...

Fields.DialogueText: Finding universal appeal? That just means it's a challenge!
True. Very few ships have much more than a bosun's whistle or the occasional harmonica.
Hmm... perhaps some visual art, then?
This problem's been keeping me up at night, to tell you the truth.
... Do you even need to sleep?
Well... no. Actually. But I like to! Sometimes.
Fair enough. I'd like to sleep more.
I feel like I'm not making much progress on it. And I invented it.
Don't force it. If you made it, you can unmake it.
I used to say that about my recruits.
Did you?
No. But if they ever got unruly, I thought about it real hard.
So that's how it is, Captain. I'm getting a lot of flak from back home.
I'm sure a lot of the other fellas are getting the same. Especially the Brits, the Germans...
Right, the actual belligerent nations. Who even knows what kind of news those folks are getting?
I couldn't begin to guess, Captain. I imagine not much. The INPF doesn't seem to censor too much, but...
But it's just a bit too much to believe. I know. All right. I'll see what I can do.
Make sure to keep an eye out for your shipmates, especially from the belligerent powers. They need our support. Dismissed.
Aye-aye, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: The same problem we've been tackling recently.

Fields.DialogueText: What was that about, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: What we expected. The home fronts putting pressure on their sailors.
For every person that believes in you Belles, it seems there's two or more doubters.

Fields.DialogueText: Mhmm. That sailor looked pretty distraught, too.
Morale is a complex problem, isn't it? It's not just the sailors, or them and their families, but whole nations.
It is hard to believe. It's not unfair for people to doubt... or jut not want to believe.
People just might not have enough context for dealing with the reality of the Morganas.
Or they're focusing on the land war. It's more immediate to them. That makes it more real.
Which makes the Morganas just another distraction.
Well, we'll just have to make it real! Then they'd treat it seriously.
Morganas! Morganas to port!
Careful what you wish for. Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Hmm... No, that's not it.
Recruit?
Ah! Captain! I was just working on some notes.
About the morale problems? Any interesting brain waves?
It's complicated.
Well, we knew that.
I think we can only really tackle this from one end: the sailors, or the general populace.
We are only one officer and one nigh-immortal warship spirit, after all.
Har har. You should have been a comedian.
Seriously, though. Which end of the problem do you think we should focus on?

Fields.MenuText: The civilian population. If we treat the source, we should get results.
The crews. Give them the tools and knowledge they need to help back home.
It's a big enough problem that I can't be sure. There's really no way to tackle the whole thing?

Fields.DialogueText: We have to start from somewhere, though the civilians might be the bigger challenge.
We have easy access to the crews and the support infrastructure to reach them, after all.
Helping with one should help the other, but I'm honestly not sure.
This was a lot easier during the Great War.
Relatively clean lines in that conflict. I even...
Hey, that's an idea!
*ALARM*
Save it! Meet you on the bridge!
Oh, you are not going to want to miss it!
@BATTLE
Damn, damn, damn! Where did I put it?
Recruit, it can wait! We're about to start shooting!
Gah! Fine. Not like this clutter's going anywhere.
@BATTLE
Hah! I knew it was here somewhere. Hey! You there! Go fetch a couple sheets and a bosun's mate.
Aye-aye, ma'am! Oh, excuse me, Captain.
Carry on. Recruit, what's all this mess?
I found it! My projector! I just need to improvise a screen.
Like a movie projector?
Precisely. It's only set up for silent films, but I bet I can wrangle an upgrade from the INPF.

Fields.MenuText: Going to show some old classics?
You know when I commented on propaganda films, that wasn't a suggestion.
Hmm. I think I see where you're going with this.

Fields.DialogueText: That's right. I have a cunning plan!
Propaganda's all what you make of it, Captain.
As expected of my captain.
As far as lifestyle changes go, I figure movie night will be an easy sell.
We can mix in some war movies, the kind to lift the spirit... some lighter fare for higher moods...
There's other types I wanted to use, but I'm pretty sure they don't exist.
Like what?
INPF training films, for one. Ship recognition, operation, some of the universal hand signals we've developed...
Sounds like something our friend Commander Redviper might be interested in.
It does indeed! I still need to think about it, but once I have a plan, would you submit the proposal?
Of course. Keep me posted. I'm curious to see what you come up with.
Well, I have to say that movie night was a rousing success!
If you do say so yourself.
And I do! Little luxuries and time away from grumpy petty officers and hard work can be worth more than rum.
Don't let the Chief hear you say that. She'll lay into you for heresy.
The Chief's an old salt before her time. Besides, even she enjoyed the movies.
Did you know I was a movie star once upon a time, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: You know, you do look familiar...
Really?
Wait, recently? Or before, when you were asleep?

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, you don't have to look at me so intensely.
You don't have to sound so surprised.
When I was asleep, of course. I'd hope you'd notice a film crew aboard.
So what movie were you--
*ALARM*
I guess that'll have to wait. Morganas!
That's our cue to hit the bridge!
@BATTLE
Look at us go! I could really use that film crew right about now...
@BATTLE
Captain! There you are. About our last conversation...
About you being a movie star?
Surely you've seen the movie I did with Charles Richman? Over There! It's a classic.

Fields.MenuText: Can't say I've ever heard of it.
Recruit, I'm pretty sure I was in short pants when that was released.
Isn't that a song?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, you wouldn't hear it. It was a silent picture!
That's no excuse for not taking in culture, Captain!
The song inspired the title of the movie, of course!
It was a great movie - all about the AEF going overseas to fight the Great War.
So how did you feature?
Who better to have in your film than a bona fide New York-class battleship?
One conveniently located on land for filming, too.
Correct! It'd be fun to remake it with all this new technology, though. I could even sing the song!
Over there, over there. Send the word, send the word over there. That the Yanks are coming!
With my sisters leading the charge, of course.
New York was the only American warship to sink an enemy ship during the Great War, you know.
... Didn't she get rammed accidentally by a U-boat?
Details, details. A kill's a kill.
You're quite proud of your sisters, aren't you?
Very. They're both amazing. Powerful. Graceful. It's a lot to live up to.
I'm sure they're proud of you, too. Even during the Great War, you were pretty impressive.
I graduated 25,000 sailors at least! They don't call me Recruit for nothing!
Captain! I've decided what my next plan is.
Ah, hello, Recruit. No, I'm not busy. Please, come in and sit down.
Har har. Seriously, though.
Well, don't keep me in suspense.
I'm going to make a movie!

Fields.MenuText: How the hell are we going to pay for that?

Fields.DialogueText: We won't, of course. The INPF will.

Fields.MenuText: Doesn't that mean going into dry dock or tying up at the pier for a while?

Fields.DialogueText: No, the entire point will be to avoid any impact on our operational status.

Fields.MenuText: Hmm. What kind of movie, though?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you asked, Captain!
I'm going to make a feature-length production like Over There.
I want to do something that'll help on the home front, and a well-done movie will do it.
I've already done up a letter to Commander Redviper. I'll send it along with your permission.
Send the message. There's no harm in seeing where this goes.
That's the spirit, Captain! This will work, I promise you!
*ALARM*
Hold that thought. I'll send the message after we send this Morgana to the bottom!
@BATTLE
Well, that was a faster response than I'd expected. HQ must be worried.
Is that from Commander Redviper?
It is. Seems the INPF's already shopped and selected a script.
They've also hired a director for the project and a crew.
That's... almost suspiciously fast.

Fields.MenuText: I suspect we made an existing plan easier by volunteering.
The INPF has to be tracking the same problems we are.
It's a golden opportunity. It'd be foolish not to jump on it.

Fields.DialogueText: That does seem likely. I wonder who they were considering before we stepped forward?
Yes. It's almost certainly fleetwide, and as the land war picks up steam... well. I suspect it'll get worse before it gets better.
I'm glad the INPF concurs with our thinking on the matter.
Still. I wonder who they got to direct.
I'm sure they got someone properly qualified.
There's a whole world out there to draw on. I've heard Japanese cinema is growing by leaps and bounds.
I should look into that. Maybe one of the Japanese Belles has some reels she can lend me.
Do you speak Japanese?
No, but for well-shot films I think you can get the feeling without speaking the language.
I hear subtitles are becoming more common, however! That's another good enterprise for morale.
What is?
Translating foreign-language films with subtitles in a lingua franca like English. Facilitates cultural exchange among the crew, and all that.
Not a bad idea, but save it for after our film project is done.
*ALARM*
And after we send this enemy fleet packing!
@BATTLE
Careful out there, Captain! We've got guests to worry about today!
One of these days you'll cut me in on these things from the start.
One of these days...
@BATTLE
Hmm. Sounds noisy out in the corridor...
Captain, I really can't let you--
Away with you! I must speak to the capitaine at once!
I'm terribly sorry, but can I help you? Petty Officer, what's going on?
Captain, this man and his entourage barged their way in across the quarterdeck and I--
Silence! I am Jean-Pierre Cousteau-Petrel, and this ship is to be my next masterpiece.
... Ah, yes, you'll be the director. That'll be all, Petty Officer. Have some sailors bring any baggage they have aboard.
Aye-aye, Captain.
Merci, Capitaine. That man was utterly insistent in stopping me reaching your quarters.
That is indeed his job. So you're prepared to get to work?
Oui, Capitaine. With me I have my master cameraman - a Greek, Monsieur Otto Phokas - and our small staff.
This environment is... spartan, as Monsieur Phokas might say... but for art we must suffer.
I heard the director had arrived, Captain!
Ah, Recruit, excellent timing. The director was just introducing himself.
A pleasure to make your acquaintance, mademoiselle.

Fields.MenuText: So how can we be of service?
Where do you intend to start?
Do you only have technical staff? No actors or anything?

Fields.DialogueText: I must familiarize myself with my surroundings, the canvas I am to create upon.
We must settle in, review the script, and prepare. We should be able to start shooting quickly.
None as of yet, Capitaine. We shall review what talent is already here and send for that which is not.
If you'd like, I can take you on a tour of... well. Myself.
That would be perfect, mademoiselle. Please, lead the way.
Why do I have a feeling like a storm's brewing all of a sudden?
Properly settled in, director?
Oui. You have my thanks for your hospitality, Capitaine... though as I feared, the food is somewhat lacking.
We are a warship in wartime. We have to make do to a certain extent.
Of course, of course. I have found some other problems with our casting.

Fields.MenuText: Casting?
Such as?
Is there anything I can do to assist?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, as in the leading actors for our film.
A... personnel problem, I believe you would call it.
Non. I have already summoned the solution to our problem.
So what is the problem, exactly?
I hesitate to say it, mademoiselle, but... the problem is you.
Me!?
Simply put, I need a more glamorous leading lady as our Belle if I am to show the world your war.
Both to attract attention from the common folk at the theater, and in terms of acting ability.
Monsieur Director, they require you below to review some plans.
Ah, pardonnez-moi. I must attend to this.
Recruit? Are you--
Why, that stuck-up, lousy--
Recruit, just calm down.
He literally just told me I'm not qualified to play myself!
... But it's for the war effort. He's the expert.
We can ask HQ for a different director. I'm sure we can--
No. I have a good feeling about him. Even if he is terribly rude.
*ALARM*
I know what will make you feel better.
Pounding some Morganas to scrap?
Pounding some Morganas to scrap.
@BATTLE
Capitaine! A moment of your time, s'il vous plaît!
Monsieur. How can I help you?
I have finalized my casting choices for the film.
Oh? Excellent. Any more actors coming aboard?
Non, the crew will suffice for the remaining roles.
I have selected you to play the Capitaine.
You want me to play myself?
Oui. Élégant, n'est-ce pas? What could be better?
Having observed you in action... magnifique!
You have a perfect commanding presence. The very picture of a naval officer.
The whole world will comprehend without words why Belles put their faith in you.
Now that I can get behind.
Ah, but my work calls. I shall bring you a copy of the script later.
Well, at least he's not completely wrong most of the time.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure how I feel about this.
I'd really rather not do this. Can I opt out?
Has anyone actually seen this script?

Fields.DialogueText: You should be excited, Captain! You really are perfect for the role.
Possibly, though I suspect the director will sulk about it. It'd take enough time to find a replacement, in any event.
No, the director's kept it under pretty tight guard. HQ had to review it, though. It should be fine.
Well, if you think I should do it...
I do, Captain! Monsieur Cousteau-Petrel's casting choice in this case is perfect.
Well, if you say so... I guess I'll do it.
Honestly, Captain, just try to enjoy yourself. You're already something of a celebrity, you know!
Don't remind me. Please.
*ALARM*
It's not often I'm relieved by the opportunity to do my actual job.
Let's not waste time, then. We'll show these scoundrels just who they're dealing with!
@BATTLE
Is this the captain?
... Yes.
Excuse me, ladies, but can I help you somehow?
Yes... yes, I can see it. It's a bit unconventional, but I like that.
Come again?
What the director sees in you. You'll clearly be the perfect co-star!
I normally don't work with amateurs, but there's raw talent there. I'm sure of it!

Fields.MenuText: Recruit? Care to explain?
I'm terribly sorry to be rude, but who the hell are you?
Ah, so this must be the actress the director was talking about.

Fields.DialogueText: Sorry, Captain. She rushed ahead more or less at random.
Captain, this is--
That's correct, Captain. May I introduce--
Sasha A. Sinclaire, at my own service and no one else's.
... Right. If you'll just follow me, Ms. Sinclaire, we'll get you settled into your quarters.
Oh, drat. I was so looking forward to getting to know the captain. Tonight at dinner, perhaps?
Ta, darling!
If it's not clear, I hate her.
I'm sure she's charming. In her own way. To someone.
I find myself doubting the director's vision more with every word out of her mouth.
Try to play nice. This is for the war effort, after all.
I'll do my best, but I'm not happy about it.
Ours is not to reason why...
Don't tempt me with thoughts of death.
Miss! I'm so sorry, but I seem to have gotten lost again. And, you know, who better to ask than the ship herself?
Oh, dear, Morganas. One of the sailors will escort you below. Quickly.
@BATTLE
Feel up to a little master class for our leading lady?
@BATTLE
Another smart remark and I'll be teaching her treason.
I simply insist! Please, won't you tell me?
Interesting to see the two of you together.
Ah, Captain, darling! We're like two peas in a pod, of course.
But to business. Could you perhaps tell me Recruit's actual name?

Fields.MenuText: ... Is that a trick question?
You just said her actual name.
USS Recruit, hull number... actually, what hull number did they give you?

Fields.DialogueText: Still none yet, Captain.
Do you perhaps not know her name as well, darling?
You're both so straight-faced when you joke. I can see why you get on so well, darling!
No trick at all! I just want to know her real name and she simply won't tell me!
Your commitment to your method acting really is commendable, you know.
I admire it greatly, but I do so wish to know your name.
Why is it so hard to understand that my name is Recruit? The Belle of this ship?
Well, that's your job, yes. But it's one more part to play, of course!
Oh, play your game! I'll find your name out eventually.
And she's gone. Sigh. Been like that all day so far.
Captain... I don't think she understands what's going on here.
That's a problem. Maybe show her how you interact with your hull?
I'll see what I can do... though I'm not terribly hopeful.
Is she watching?
@BATTLE
Scattered at the first sign of smoke. Actresses...
I'm telling you, I'm the ship. Here, watch. I'll adjust and aim my aft turret.
See? It's as easy for me as breathing.
What a marvelous trick! How do you do it?
It's not a trick. I just do it. Captain, can you help explain?

Fields.MenuText: Ms. Sinclaire, really, Recruit is the ship.
Surely you've read the papers and heard about Belles?
I'm not sure anyone can help explain this.

Fields.DialogueText: Ship's mascot, I understand! And I'll get a turn at it - on film only, of course.
Hmm? Heard about them on the radio, but it's so outlandish. I can't help but wonder what Mr. Welles will come up with next.
Explain what, darling?
This is impossible.
Honestly, though, Ms. Recruit, I don't see why the director needs me.
I'm sorry, what?
Well, I'm obviously beautiful and well known, but with such a talented method actor I'm not sure looks will count for much.
I can see why the sailors are so inspired by you!
You... can? But you don't... Belles?
See? Amazing expressions! Now that's talent. A little help with makeup and I think you'd be perfect!
Yes! That touch of red to your complexion is perfect. A little blush for everyday use and...
... You know, I'm just... going to run to the bridge now. Duty calls!
Get back here, you coward!
Ah, Captain, darling, there you are!
... Please, just as a favor to me. Please stop calling the captain that.
Darling, I'm so glad I found you. I was wondering if you might be available to help me.
... Well, we'll certainly do our best to make your stay somewhat comfortable, Ms. Sinclaire.
Please, all my friends call me Sasha. And I do so dearly wish to be your friend, darling.
I was hoping we might get to know each other a bit better.
As co-stars it's quite important that we have chemistry... and I must admit that you are quite striking.
Mr. Cousteau-Petrel really does have an eye for raw talent!
That's flattering, Ms. Sinclaire. But really, I...
I have some special supplies I brought with me. Fine wine fine food... I'd love for you to join me for dinner.
I so dearly want to make your intimate acquaintance, darling.
Won't you please join me? Consider it a favor for little old me.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry, Ms. Sinclaire. I'm taken.
Like any good naval officer, I'm married to my ship and to the sea.
Honestly, I'm flattered, but my first responsibility must be to humanity itself.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, that's right. The captain's... wait. Taken by who, exactly!
Yes, married to your ship and the... wait. Captain, you can't just say things like that! Someone might misunderstand!
Did you have a lawyer write that for you? Or did you come up with it yourself?
Married to your job, eh? I admire that kind of dedication, Captain.
So you'll leave the captain alo--
That just makes me want to pursue you more!
Oh, for the love of Columbia!
*ALARM*
Never have I ever been more grateful for an enemy attack.
You and me both. You get below, Ms. Sinclaire. We have to get to the bridge.
Do show the Germans or whoever we're fighting what for, you two! Oh, or is this another scene?
Wait... scene?
Recruit!
Coming, Captain!
@BATTLE
"Is this another scene." I'll make her the star of the loudest, most violent--
Recruit.
Just some vocal exercises, Captain.
@BATTLE
Get that sailor below decks to sick bay!
Make a hole, damn it! Wounded coming through.
Honestly, your commitment to your roles is really impressive.
... This is literally our job. We're in the middle of a war! Now please, clear the deck.
Oh, I will. I was just watching. Such incredible special effects, though!
They're so wildly realistic. I feel like the people who jumped at the train racing toward the camera!

Fields.MenuText: Recruit, what the hell is she talking about?

Fields.DialogueText: Honestly, Captain, I'm as confused as you are.

Fields.MenuText: Special eff... Ms. Sinclaire, this isn't a movie set.

Fields.DialogueText: Trust me, everything we're doing is very real.

Fields.MenuText: No. You've been aboard for a while now. There's no way you don't get that this is real.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure anyone can actually be this dense.
Oh, poo, you're both being far too serious. Still, you have to respect Stanislavski's system and all that. Ta!
I blame Orson Welles for this.
What? Why?
The War of the Worlds broadcast was apparently quite realistic. Not that anyone believed it was real.
But by setting the standard high for the fantastic in a grounded sort of way... we've got an uphill battle in some places.
People don't want to believe the Morganas are real. Or Belles, for that matter.
It's not hard to understand why. Who would want to believe we're in a situation where we need Belles?
Hopefully our movie opens people's eyes. Though with Sasha playing me...
I think we need to talk to Jean-Pierre. Sasha's clearly not suited to play you.
I'm glad you concur, Captain. Come on, let's get back to work.
Hmm...
Recruit? What are you doing?
Oh! Captain! You surprised me. I'm watching Ms. Sinclaire.
What's she doing?
Wandering around the deck, looking at things. I think she's trying to find rigging for special effects.
Oh! Hello, you two! Seems like you're always together when I see you. I envy your intimate relationship.

Fields.MenuText: As I said before, a captain is married to their ship. Usually metaphorically, but lately...
We're close friends and we work together.
Ms. Sinclaire, I won't comment on my relationships when I'm working.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, you're saying things people might misunderstand again!
Very close. Like alloy steel.
That's right! The captain is a picture perfect professional, mostly.
I was going to ask you more about the effects, but I see the ships for the next scene coming.
I'm terribly sorry, what?
See? On the horizon there.
Damn it. Get Ms. Sinclaire below and meet me on the bridge!
Aye-aye, Captain!
Wait! No, please, I'd love to have a better seat to watch the action!
No can do. Move or I move you!
@BATTLE
What a lovely day to start shooting. I think I've got a good grasp on how to play you, Recruit.
What about you, Captain? Have you had a chance to read the script?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Oh, I guess we're starting early.
I heard you were shooting a movie. You should have sent me an invitation!
That voice on the radio... Vanity! Damn, she really is the worst camera hound.
Incoming! Ms. Sinclaire, don't just stand there! Move!
This... this isn't just a set!

Fields.MenuText: I hate to say we told you so.

Fields.DialogueText: But we absolutely told you so.

Fields.MenuText: We've been trying to explain that to you since you came aboard.

Fields.DialogueText: Honestly, if you were any deeper in denial, you'd be studying Cleopatra's role.

Fields.MenuText: Welcome to the real world. We've been expecting you.

Fields.DialogueText: You might have been, Captain. I'm shocked she made the trip.
I'm not getting paid enough to put up with this madness!
At last we agree on something.
Well, I'll make it easy on you. I'm quitting! Or at least negotiating hazard pay!
I'm going to get my agent on the horn, and then I'm getting off this thing!
Don't let the hatch hit you on the way out.
The director's going to be annoyed.
Finally it's someone else's turn.
Again, I really must apologize. I had no idea Ms. Sinclaire was that oblivious.
Honestly, Director, I'm surprised you're taking it so well.
I am an artist, mademoiselle. Audacity and madness are simply part of a day's work.
I do owe both of you a further apology, however. After observing you, I've realized I was quite wrong to hire Sasha.

Fields.MenuText: Did you have a better actress in mind or something?

Fields.DialogueText: Anyone would likely be better than her.

Fields.MenuText: Was it me you needed to replace after all?

Fields.DialogueText: Better not be.

Fields.MenuText: You can't beat the real thing in the end.

Fields.DialogueText: I agree completely.
Really, it's the two of you. You're perfect for my vision. Your chemistry in combat, with each other... The two of you are an ideal on-screen couple!
I have also found out that one of my cameramen has been filming some of the battles since first we arrived.
I have decided to minimize the impact on your operations by using as much real combat footage as possible.
Well, that will certainly get people's attention.
We'll have to clear that with the INPF, but that sounds ideal to me.
Of course it is. I'll still need scenes with the two of you and other crew, of course.
We've wasted far too much time on all this! We must start at once!
*ALARM*
Perhaps it'll need to wait.
Non, c'est parfait! Quick! Get the cameras rolling!
@BATTLE
Isn't this exciting, Captain? It's just like the real thing!
That is not what she sounded like.
Oh, you were thinking it too.
@BATTLE
Coupez! Everyone take a brief break.
I haven't memorized this much text since I was a kid.
I haven't done it ever. I'm a doctor, not an actress.
On the plus side, most of the work seems to be recording actual things we said in combat.
Repeating myself out of the moment feels so odd, though.

Fields.MenuText: I wonder if this madcap plan's actually going to work.
They're going to need a genius editor to get this vaguely coherent.
The Morganas are certainly obliging the director's desire for combat footage.

Fields.DialogueText: I think it'll work. Probably.
I'm sure the INPF and the director have a plan. He's supposed to really know his stuff.
I'm not sure if that's fortunate or unfortunate, really. Both, I suppose.
At least we convinced him to reduce the film crew on the bridge to just a few men.
It was getting hard to move!
I think it's a great idea to film actual events while we can, but I'm not sure he fully understands the danger we're in.
Or maybe he does and just doesn't care?
One must be prepared to suffer for art!
Not a bad imitation. We'll make an actress of you yet.
What can I say? My co-star inspires me.
Coupez! Magnifique! C'est dans la boîte!
I'm terribly sorry, Director, but what does that mean?
Ah, excusez-moi. In English: "It's in the can." The filming is done, and the editing can begin!
Which means it is time for me to take my leave.
You've both done wonderfully for amateurs. Should you ever want to get into show business, do give me a call.
Leaving as suddenly as he arrived, I see.

Fields.MenuText: Had enough acting for now, Recruit?

Fields.DialogueText: More than enough. Starring in Over There was much easier. No lines to worry about!

Fields.MenuText: I understand the purpose, but I'm glad that's over with.

Fields.DialogueText: Now we just have to wait and see if it works.

Fields.MenuText: Finally. I was worried he'd never go!

Fields.DialogueText: It will certainly be quieter without a film crew getting underfoot.
Thank you for going along with my crazy idea, Captain. I really appreciate it.
Anything for you, Recruit.
You did it again, Captain. A girl might get the wrong idea, you know.
I think you're getting exactly the idea I want you to.
I'm feeling a bit warm all of a sudden. The chief engineer must be stoking the boilers.
If you say so. Let's get back to work, shall we?
@BATTLE
It's quiet.
If you think I'm about to say "too quiet," you've got another thing coming.
I think we're about to have quite enough chaos right now.
@BATTLE
Once more... it's quiet. For real this time.
Just not having that woman around alone is doing wonders for my composure.
*ALARM*
You really didn't like her, did you?
She's the opposite of me, I think. I might be proud, but I try not to be vain.
And I most certainly don't try to live with my head in the sand.

Fields.MenuText: For now we see in a mirror, darkly...

Fields.DialogueText: Seeing Sasha in my mirror would be a dark day indeed.

Fields.MenuText: I don't know. I think you could have become friends with Sasha if you'd wanted.

Fields.DialogueText: If I'd wanted, Captain, dear.

Fields.MenuText: Well, thankfully, we aren't likely to hear from Sasha Sinclaire again.

Fields.DialogueText: And I'd call that a picture perfect ending in my book.
Could I offer you some tea, Captain? Or something stronger, perhaps?
Almost feels like we need to have a toast now that we're done.
Whatever we do, as long as we do it together... it's celebration enough for me.
Careful, Recruit. A captain might get the wrong idea if you keep saying things like that.
I think you're getting exactly tthe idea I want you to, Captain.
Speaking of which. Join me for dinner soon?
Recruit, I can safely say that it would be my pleasure.
Captain! Message from Commander Redviper! It's hot off the decoder's desk.
Oh, really? Let's have a look.
Come on, Captain, let's get back to work!
Film reviewed, excellent work, going to syndication... huh. Seems we have a winner on our hands.
The admiralty board was pleased, most of the national representatives were pleased... All in all, an enthusiastic job well done from HQ.
Apparently we got a two for one deal, too. Sasha Sinclaire has been making dramatic statements about the war to the press. She's turning a lot of heads.
Still. Not a bad little adventure, eh, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Well, all's well that ends well, I guess.

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing we can really do but shrug and see what tomorrow brings.

Fields.MenuText: If the movie does too well, we might get roped into a sequel.
Maybe we should have more famous types tag along for a whiff of combat.

Fields.DialogueText: With you as my co-star, that's not such a bad deal.
It's all fun and games until some actress gets caught in some blast radius.
No, not bad at all. I'm looking forward to seeing what's over the horizon.
Morganas. Lots and lots of Morganas.
Good thing I have a battleship like you at my side, then.
That's right! You should appreciate having a beauty like me on your arm.
In and out of battle.
I suppose I'll have to show you my appreciation more often.
I can think of a few ways you--
*ALARM*
All right, who's the slimy, scrap-for-brains, pile-of-spare-parts bitch who just signed her own death warrant!?
Whoever it is, it's personal this time.
